title: Mr. Johnson's Journey with Hip Osteoarthritis
clinical_history: Mr. James Johnson is a 67-year-old retired carpenter. He initially started experiencing discomfort in his right hip approximately 3 years ago. Gradually, this discomfort has evolved into a persistent, deep, aching pain localized mainly around the right groin and extending to the anterior thigh. His pain level exacerbates with certain movements like standing for more than 10-15 minutes or during prolonged walks. Occasionally, Mr. Johnson feels a grinding sensation in his hip joint. The pain is worse in the morning and tends to ease off slightly after some movement but then increases again as the day progresses.
aggrevating_factors: Standing for more than 15 minutes, walking more than a few blocks, certain twisting motions, and rising after prolonged sitting.
picture: [insert image highlighting right hip and adjacent areas]
easing_factors: Mild movements, heat packs, and over-the-counter pain relief medication.
past_history: Mr. Johnson has a history of labor-intensive work as a carpenter, contributing to significant wear and tear on his joints. There is a family history of osteoarthritis; his father and older brother also were diagnosed in their later years.
medical_history: Mr. Johnson has managed high blood pressure for the past 7 years, which is well-controlled with medication.
medications: Acetaminophen as needed for pain relief. Lisinopril for hypertension.
personal_history: Mr. Johnson lives with his wife of 42 years. He enjoys woodworking as a hobby, though his hip pain has limited his shop time recently. They have two adult children and three grandchildren who live nearby.
imaging: Right hip X-Ray confirms joint space narrowing and the presence of osteophytes indicative of osteoarthritis.
